moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 c5 3. d5 e6 4. Nc3 exd5:
The old main line benoni, I believe ECO E73.

(Taken from MCO 15)... "The Benoni defense strives for imbalance from the start. Black cedes White more central territory with an advanced pawn on d5 and normally a kingside pawn majority. Black in turn normally gets dark-square play in the center and an extra queenside pawn which can be dangerous if mobilized.
moves.10... Nbd7: eyeing e5, black plays on the dark squares in the center.
moves.11. f3: I was surprised not to see a4, surpressing black's queenside play, or f4, thrusting into the center.
moves.11... Ne5 12. Nc4:
12. f4? Neg4
Nc4 challenges the dark squares nicely.
moves.12... Nxc4 13. Bxc4 a6: preparing a pawn thrust on the queenside, trying to make use of the majority.
moves.14... Nh5: Better for me probably would have been Nd7, with the juicy b6 and e5 squares in the knight's sight. I chose h5, however, because of the weak f4 square.
moves.16. Qe1 Qf6: black plays harder on the dark squares, and he is already seemingly better because white failed to utilize his center pawns well.
moves.17. Qd2 Nf4: black's pieces are invasive and annoying to the white center.
moves.19. Ne2 Nxe2+ 20. Qxe2: perhaps Bxe2 was worth a look as well.
moves.21. f4: I believe g3 may have been the better way to stop Qxh2, as this opens the h5-d1 diagonal for the black bishop. After Bxe2, this wouldn't be a problem...
moves.21... Bg7 22. Bd3 f5: opening the E file could prove to be deadly for white. 23. exf4 Bg4
moves.23. Qf3: This fails tactically, as white's position crumbles to dust.
moves.27. g3: better was h3 here for white, but he's already a goner, and is playing sloppily until the end.
moves.28... Bf5: Seeing he's going to lose yet another pawn, white resigns.

gameName: Thematic Benoni 6 for FAST players only
